Defective dual varieties for real spectra

Jens Forsgård Université de Genève, Mathématiques, Villa Battelle, 1227 Carouge, Suisse. Jens.Forsgaard@unige.ch
Abstract.

We introduce an invariant of a finite point configuration A⊂ℝ1+n𝐴superscriptℝ1𝑛A\subset\mathbb{R}^{1+n} which we denote the cuspidal form of A𝐴A. We use this invariant to extend Esterov’s characterization of dual defective point configurations to exponential sums; the dual variety associated to A𝐴A has codimension at least 222 if and only if A𝐴A does not contain any iterated circuit.

1. Introduction

The main undertaking of fewnomial theory is to bound the number of connected components of the positive part of a variety defined by a system of equations solely in terms of the number of variables n𝑛n and the total number of monomials N𝑁N appearing in the system. Since the constitutive monograph [10] of Khovanskiĭ, fewnomial theory has often been studied alongside the theory of exponential sums. After all, the coordinatewise exponential map exp:ℝn→ℝ+n:→superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptsubscriptℝ𝑛\exp\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n} is a diffeomorpism and replacing monomials zαsuperscript𝑧𝛼z^{\alpha} by exponentials e⟨w,α⟩superscript𝑒𝑤𝛼e^{\langle w,\alpha\rangle} the fundamental examples (read: Descartes’ rule of signs) remain valid.

Lately, fewnomial theory has also been studied from the viewpoint of Gel’fand, Kapranov, and Zelevinsky’s “A𝐴A-philosophy.” In this approach, one considers the family of all polynomials which can be expressed using a fixed set (the support set) A𝐴A of exponent vectors α𝛼\alpha. For example, in [1] the bound on the number of positive solutions of a system of equations supported on a circuit was sharpened by considering in addition the combinatorics of A𝐴A.

Seldom has the two approaches been combined. We are aware only of [12], where the A𝐴A-discriminant and its Horn–Kapranov uniformization was generalized to the case of exponential sums. We put ourself in this setting, and consider the family

(ℂ×)A={f​(w)=∑α∈Acα​e⟨w,α⟩|cα∈ℂ×},superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴conditional-set𝑓𝑤subscript𝛼𝐴subscript𝑐𝛼superscript𝑒𝑤𝛼subscript𝑐𝛼superscriptℂ(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A}=\bigg{\{}\,f(w)=\sum_{\alpha\in A}c_{\alpha}\,e^{\langle w,\alpha\rangle}\,\bigg{|}\,c_{\alpha}\in\mathbb{C}^{\times}\,\bigg{\}},

where A⊂ℝ1+n𝐴superscriptℝ1𝑛A\subset\mathbb{R}^{1+n} is a finite set, and N=#​A𝑁#𝐴N=\#A. We have many names for those we love; the support set A𝐴A is also known as the Bohr spectrum (or, simply, spectrum) of an exponential sum f∈(ℂ×)A𝑓superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴f\in(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A}.

The work presented in this article emerged from an innocent question of whether a theorem of Katz [9] holds also in the framework of exponential sums. The answer is affirmative, as we show in Theorem 3.5. This theorem has already seen an application in [6] to reduce a fewnomial hypersurface bound from exponential to subexponential in the dimension. Our main line of thought goes, however, in a slightly different direction.

We associate to the spectrum A⊂ℝ1+n𝐴superscriptℝ1𝑛A\subset\mathbb{R}^{1+n} a combinatorial invariant in the form of a homogeneous polynomial PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) of degree n𝑛n, which we call the cuspidal form of A𝐴A, see Definition 3.1. Here, t𝑡t denotes the parameters of the Horn–Kapranov uniformization of the A𝐴A-discriminant XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} and, hence, the cuspidal form depends also on a choice of Gale dual of A𝐴A. The name “cuspidal form” reflects the fact that PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) describes the preimage of the cuspidal locus of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} under the Horn–Kapranov uniformaziation. In particular, as one observes immediately, the configuration A𝐴A is dual defective if and only if PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is trivial.

The core part of this work is to describe the properties of the cuspidal form PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) as an invariant of the spectrum A𝐴A. Our main, technical, results are concerned with factorizations. For example, if A𝐴A is a diagonal configuration (Definition 4.3), then the cuspidal form PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) factors as a product of the cuspidal forms of the diagonal configurations of A𝐴A.

We spend a fair amount of energy describing linear factors of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). These are of two distinct types. The first type consists of linear factors corresponding to rows of the Gale dual. These factors correspond to points α∈A𝛼𝐴\alpha\in A such that A∖{α}𝐴𝛼A\setminus\{\alpha\} is dual defective. Such factors are studied in §4.1 and §5. The complementary type corresponds to discriminant varieties embedded into the cuspidal locus of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A}. This generalizes results of [11], where the cuspidal form first appeared in the special case of n=1𝑛1n=1 (when PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is itself a linear form).

As an application, we extend Esterov’s characterization from [4] and [5] of dual defective point configurations to the case of exponential sums: A point configuration A𝐴A is dual defective if and only if it does not contain any iterated circuit (Theorem 6.4). Our proof uses in addition to the properties of the cuspidal form only the pidgeon hole principle.

Finally, in §8 we study the special case n=2𝑛2n=2 when PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is a quadratic form. Defined only up to choice of coordinates of the parameter space ℂmsuperscriptℂ𝑚\mathbb{C}^{m} of the Horn–Kapranov uniformization, it is natural to consider the rank of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). We consider instead the signature of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t), which is a well-defined invariant of A𝐴A if we restrict to real Gale duals. It turns out (Theorem 8.1) that the rank of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is at most 333, independent on the number of variables m𝑚m. The degenerate case that the rank is at most 222 occurs if and only if the spectrum A𝐴A is contained in a conic section; the type of the conic section is described by the signature of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). These results relate to the study of self-dual toric varieties as follows. Given a two-dimensional (integral) point configuration A𝐴A, the cusps of of the associated toric variety XAsubscript𝑋𝐴X_{A} are (intuitively) contained in two lines. Hence, if XAsubscript𝑋𝐴X_{A} is self dual, then PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) factors into linear forms, implying by Theorem 8.1 that A𝐴A is contained in a conic section. For an explicit example, see the description of the Togliatti surface in [3, §4.1], whose spectrum consists of six points on an ellipse.

It is possible toconsider for example complex spectra instead of real. The A𝐴A-discriminant variety, in the sense of exponential sums, remains well-defined. The characterization of dual defective point configurations, as those who do not contain an iterated circuit, remains valid. However, for complex spectra, the relationship to combinatorics is lost, as we can for example not talk about Newton polygons. We have chosen to stay in the real world as this is the most interesting case for applications.

1.1. Acknowledges

I would like to thank Professor Ragni Piene for the helpful discussions, and Professor J. Maurice Rojas for the inspiration.

2. Prelude: Gale Duality and the Horn–Kapranov Uniformization

2.1. The setup

By ordering the elements of A𝐴A we obtain an isomorphism ℂA≃ℂNsimilar-to-or-equalssuperscriptℂ𝐴superscriptℂ𝑁\mathbb{C}^{A}\simeq\mathbb{C}^{N}. With an ordering chosen, by abuse of notation, we identify A𝐴A with the (1+n)×N1𝑛𝑁(1+n)\times N-matrix A=(α1,…,αN)𝐴subscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑁A=\big{(}\alpha_{1},\dots,\alpha_{N}\big{)}. Doing so, we often write cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} for the coefficient of e⟨w,αk⟩superscript𝑒𝑤subscript𝛼𝑘e^{\langle w,\alpha_{k}\rangle}, and identify an exponential sum f𝑓f with its (column) coefficient vector c=(c1,…,cN)T𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝑁𝑇c=(c_{1},\dots,c_{N})^{T}.

The properties of the exponential sum f𝑓f which we are interested in (e.g., the existence of a singular point) are invariant of linear changes of variables. That is, if we denote by MN,n​(ℝ)subscript𝑀𝑁𝑛ℝM_{N,n}(\mathbb{R}) the space of all such matrices A𝐴A, then we are interested in the orbits under the left action of GL1+n⁡(ℝ)subscriptGL1𝑛ℝ\operatorname{GL}_{1+n}(\mathbb{R}).

If A⊂ℤ​𝕚​𝕖​𝟡𝟝1+n𝐴ℤ𝕚𝕖superscript951𝑛A\subset\mathbb{Zie95}^{1+n}, then the exponential sum is said to be polynomial, and the configuration A𝐴A is said to be algebraic. In this case, we can associate to f𝑓f the polynomial g​(z)=∑α∈Acα​zα𝑔𝑧subscript𝛼𝐴subscript𝑐𝛼superscript𝑧𝛼g(z)=\sum_{\alpha\in A}c_{\alpha}\,z^{\alpha}. The analytic variety Z​(f)𝑍𝑓Z(f) is an infinite covering of the quasi-affine variety Z​(g)⊂(ℂ×)1+n𝑍𝑔superscriptsuperscriptℂ1𝑛Z(g)\subset(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{1+n}. We often descend to the algebraic case in examples.

Two natural assumptions are imposed. Firstly, A𝐴A is assumed to be pseudo-homogeneous. That is, we assume the existence of a linear form ξ∈Hom⁡(ℝ1+n,ℝ)𝜉Homsuperscriptℝ1𝑛ℝ\xi\in\operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^{1+n},\mathbb{R}) such that ⟨ξ,α⟩=1𝜉𝛼1\langle\xi,\alpha\rangle=1 for all α∈A𝛼𝐴\alpha\in A. Secondly, it is assumed that ξ𝜉\xi is unique. These two assumptions are equivalent to that the matrix A𝐴A is of full rank (equal to 1+n1𝑛1+n) with the all ones vector in its row span. In particular, the Newton polygon 𝒩=Conv⁡(α1,…,αN)𝒩Convsubscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑁\mathcal{N}=\operatorname{Conv}\big{(}\alpha_{1},\dots,\alpha_{N}\big{)} has dimension n𝑛n. We do not assume that the columns of A𝐴A are distinct.

We associate to A𝐴A the map expAsubscript𝐴\exp_{A} given by

expA:ℂ1+n→(ℂ×)N,z↦(e⟨w,α1⟩,…,e⟨w,αN⟩)T,:subscript𝐴formulae-sequence→superscriptℂ1𝑛superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝑁maps-to𝑧superscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑤subscript𝛼1…superscript𝑒𝑤subscript𝛼𝑁𝑇\exp_{A}\colon\mathbb{C}^{1+n}\rightarrow(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{N},\quad z\mapsto\big{(}e^{\langle w,\alpha_{1}\rangle},\dots,e^{\langle w,\alpha_{N}\rangle}\big{)}^{T},

where ℂNsuperscriptℂ𝑁\mathbb{C}^{N} should be considered as the dual space of ℂAsuperscriptℂ𝐴\mathbb{C}^{A}. In the algebraic case, the map expAsubscript𝐴\exp_{A} parametrizes a toric variety denoted XA⊂(ℂ×)Nsubscript𝑋𝐴superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝑁X_{A}\subset(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{N}. Its projectively dual XˇA⊂(ℂ×)Asubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴\check{X}_{A}\subset(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A} is known as the A𝐴A-discriminantal variety, see [7]. In the case that A𝐴A is algebraic and XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is a hypersurface, its defining polynomial DAsubscript𝐷𝐴D_{A} is called the A𝐴A-discriminant. In the algebraic case, by definition, DA​(c)=0subscript𝐷𝐴𝑐0D_{A}(c)=0 if and only if the polynomial g𝑔g has a singular point in (ℂ×)nsuperscriptsuperscriptℂ𝑛(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{n}. In the general case we define XˇA⊂(ℂ×)Asubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴\check{X}_{A}\subset(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A} by that f∈XˇA𝑓subscriptˇ𝑋𝐴f\in\check{X}_{A} if and only if the exponential sum f𝑓f has a singular point in ℂnsuperscriptℂ𝑛\mathbb{C}^{n}. In general, XˇA⊂(ℂ×)Asubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴\check{X}_{A}\subset(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A} is not algebraic for real spectra.

Example 2.1.

A point configuration A𝐴A is said to be a pyramid if all points but one is contained in some strict affine subspace. It is straightforward to check that if A𝐴A is a pyramid, then the discriminant locus XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is empty.

Example 2.2.

The codimension m𝑚m of a spectrum A𝐴A is given by m=N−n−1𝑚𝑁𝑛1m=N-n-1. A point configuration of codimension 111, which is not a pyramid, is said to be a circuit. Let us consider a circuit in two dimensions. Using the GL1+n⁡(ℝ)subscriptGL1𝑛ℝ\operatorname{GL}_{1+n}(\mathbb{R})-action, we can assume that A𝐴A is of the form

A=(1111010α11001α12).𝐴1111010subscript𝛼11001subscript𝛼12A=\left(\begin{array}[]{cccc}1&1&1&1\\ 0&1&0&\alpha_{11}\\ 0&0&1&\alpha_{12}\end{array}\right).

The formula of the discriminant DA​(c)subscript𝐷𝐴𝑐D_{A}(c) in the algebraic case, from [7, p. 274], generalizes to the binomial exponential expression

DA​(c)=(α11+α12−1)α11+α12−1​c0​c1α11​c2α12+(−c0​α11)α11​(−c0​α12)α12.subscript𝐷𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝛼11subscript𝛼121subscript𝛼11subscript𝛼121subscript𝑐0superscriptsubscript𝑐1subscript𝛼11superscriptsubscript𝑐2subscript𝛼12superscriptsubscript𝑐0subscript𝛼11subscript𝛼11superscriptsubscript𝑐0subscript𝛼12subscript𝛼12D_{A}(c)=(\alpha_{11}+\alpha_{12}-1)^{\alpha_{11}+\alpha_{12}-1}c_{0}c_{1}^{\alpha_{11}}c_{2}^{\alpha_{12}}+(-c_{0}\alpha_{11})^{\alpha_{11}}(-c_{0}\alpha_{12})^{\alpha_{12}}.

The multivaluedness of the exponential functions require some caution when handling this expression. For this reason, we refrain from using the A𝐴A-discriminant DA​(c)subscript𝐷𝐴𝑐D_{A}(c) in our analysis.

Remark 2.3.

In examples, it is more convenient to consider a family of inhomogeneous n𝑛n-variate exponential sums. For an exponential sum f𝑓f in the variables z1,…,znsubscript𝑧1…subscript𝑧𝑛z_{1},\dots,z_{n}, the corresponding pseudo-homogeneous exponential sum is given by ez0​fsuperscript𝑒subscript𝑧0𝑓e^{z_{0}}f. For a family of n𝑛n-variate inhomogeneous polynomials with support set A𝐴A this corresponds to adjoining a top row of all ones in its matrix representation. In this case, ξ=(1,0,…,0)𝜉10…0\xi=(1,0,\dots,0).

2.2. The Horn–Kapranov uniformization

Our main tool is the Horn–Kapranov uniformization of the A𝐴A-discriminant hypersurface from [8]. For exponential sums, this map was deduced in [12, Thm. 1.7]. Though, step-by-step, the standard deduction of the Horn–Kapranov uniformization (cf. [2, Prop. 4.1]) is sufficient to cover also the case of exponential sums.

A Gale dual of A𝐴A is a matrix B𝐵B yielding an exact sequence of ℂℂ\mathbb{C}-vector spaces

Since A𝐴A has full rank, the rank of B𝐵B is m𝑚m. Let us denote the rows of B𝐵B by βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} for k=1,…,N𝑘1…𝑁k=1,\dots,N, and let us introduce coordinates t𝑡t in ℂmsuperscriptℂ𝑚\mathbb{C}^{m}. Let ℂBmsuperscriptsubscriptℂ𝐵𝑚\mathbb{C}_{B}^{m} denote the inverse image of (ℂ×)Asuperscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A} under the map B𝐵B. The exceptional locus ℋB=ℂm∖ℂBmsubscriptℋ𝐵superscriptℂ𝑚superscriptsubscriptℂ𝐵𝑚\mathcal{H}_{B}=\mathbb{C}^{m}\setminus\mathbb{C}_{B}^{m} is the union of the linear subspaces βk∗superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}^{*}. Assuming that A𝐴A is not a pyramid (i.e., assuming that no βk=0subscript𝛽𝑘0\beta_{k}=0), then ℋBsubscriptℋ𝐵\mathcal{H}_{B} is a central hyperplane arrangement.

Theorem 2.4 (Kapranov, Rojas–Rusak).

The dual variety XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is parametrized by the map

Φ:(ℂ×)1+n×ℂBm→(ℂ×)A,Φ​(ω;t)=expA⁡(ω)∗(B​t),:Φformulae-sequence→superscriptsuperscriptℂ1𝑛subscriptsuperscriptℂ𝑚𝐵superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴Φ𝜔𝑡subscript𝐴𝜔𝐵𝑡\Phi\colon(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{1+n}\times\mathbb{C}^{m}_{B}\rightarrow(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A},\quad\Phi(\omega;t)=\exp_{A}(\omega)*(Bt),

where ∗* denotes component-wise multiplication. ∎

The map ΦΦ\Phi is far from injective; the parameter space and (ℂ×)Asuperscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A} has the same dimensions, N=1+n+m𝑁1𝑛𝑚N=1+n+m. However, that ΦΦ\Phi is homogeneous in t𝑡t and the existence of the linear form ξ𝜉\xi implies that ΦΦ\Phi parametrizes a strict (multivalued) analytic subvariety of (ℂ×)Asuperscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A}.

Remark 2.5.

In the algebraic case, the A𝐴A-discriminantal polynomial has 1+n1𝑛1+n homogeneities, arising from the matrix A𝐴A. In Kapranov’s paper [8], these homogeneities was removed by composition with the map expB:(ℂ×)A→(ℂ×)m:subscript𝐵→superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝐴superscriptsuperscriptℂ𝑚\exp_{B}\colon(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A}\rightarrow(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{m}. The composite map is, in this algebraic case, a rational function of t𝑡t. To avoid real powers of linear forms we settle for the map ΦΦ\Phi of Theorem 2.4.

Remark 2.6.

The exponential sum f=Φ​(ω;t)𝑓Φ𝜔𝑡f=\Phi(\omega;t) has a singular point with coordinates w=−ω𝑤𝜔w=-\omega.

2.3. Gale duality

Let us describe a well-known property of Gale duality. Since A𝐴A has full rank, we can find a non-vanishing maximal minor |A1|subscript𝐴1|A_{1}| of A𝐴A. After possibly rearranging the columns of A𝐴A, we can write it in the block form A=(A1,A2)𝐴subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2A=(A_{1},A_{2}). Let us extend A𝐴A to a square matrix A¯¯𝐴\bar{A}, with determinant =1absent1=1, and inverse B¯¯𝐵\bar{B}:

(1) A¯=(A1A2∗)andB¯=(∗B2B1).formulae-sequence¯𝐴subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2missing-subexpressionand¯𝐵subscript𝐵2missing-subexpressionsubscript𝐵1\bar{A}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}A_{1}&A_{2}\\ &*\end{array}\right)\quad\text{and}\quad\bar{B}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}*&B_{2}\\ &B_{1}\end{array}\right).

From B¯¯𝐵\bar{B} we obtain the Gale dual

(2) B=(B2B1).𝐵subscript𝐵2subscript𝐵1B=\left(\begin{array}[]{c}B_{2}\\ B_{1}\end{array}\right).
Lemma 2.7.

Let B𝐵B be any Gale dual of A𝐴A, and let σ⊂[N]𝜎delimited-[]𝑁\sigma\subset[N] be a choice of 1+n1𝑛1+n indices with sign sgn⁡(σ)=∏k∈σ(−1)ksgn𝜎subscriptproduct𝑘𝜎superscript1𝑘\operatorname{sgn}(\sigma)=\prod_{k\in\sigma}(-1)^{k}. Denote by Aσsubscript𝐴𝜎A_{\sigma} the maximal cofactor of A𝐴A obtained by keeping the columns indexed by σ𝜎\sigma and let Bσsubscript𝐵𝜎B_{\sigma} denote the complementary maximal cofactor of B𝐵B obtained by deleting the rows indexed by σ𝜎\sigma. Then, there is a nonzero constant C​(B)𝐶𝐵C(B), independent of σ𝜎\sigma, such that

|Aσ|=C​(B)​sgn⁡(σ)​|Bσ|.subscript𝐴𝜎𝐶𝐵sgn𝜎subscript𝐵𝜎|A_{\sigma}|=C(B)\operatorname{sgn}(\sigma)\,|B_{\sigma}|.
Proof.

Two Gale duals differ only by multiplication by a a matrix T∈GLm⁡(ℝ)𝑇subscriptGL𝑚ℝT\in\operatorname{GL}_{m}(\mathbb{R}). Thus, it suffices to prove the theorem for one explicit Gale dual B𝐵B. Indeed, if B′=B​Tsuperscript𝐵′𝐵𝑇B^{\prime}=BT, then C​(B′)=C​(B)​|T|𝐶superscript𝐵′𝐶𝐵𝑇C(B^{\prime})=C(B)\,|T|.

Let A1,A2,B1,B2,A¯subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵1subscript𝐵2¯𝐴A_{1},A_{2},B_{1},B_{2},\bar{A}, and B¯¯𝐵\bar{B} be as in (1). We claim that C​(B)=1𝐶𝐵1C(B)=1 in this case. Since |A1|≠0subscript𝐴10|A_{1}|\neq 0, we can perform row operations on A¯¯𝐴\bar{A}, which does not alter its determinant, to eliminate all entries in the bottom left block. This corresponds to multiplication by some lower triangular matrix E𝐸E of the form

(3) E=(I0I).𝐸𝐼0missing-subexpression𝐼E=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}I&0\\ &I\end{array}\right).

Notice that E−1superscript𝐸1E^{-1} has the same form as E𝐸E. We have that E​A¯​B¯​E−1=I𝐸¯𝐴¯𝐵superscript𝐸1𝐼E\bar{A}\bar{B}E^{-1}=I. It follows that

B¯​E−1=(∗B2B1),andE​A¯=(A1A20B1−1).formulae-sequence¯𝐵superscript𝐸1subscript𝐵2missing-subexpressionsubscript𝐵1and𝐸¯𝐴subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴20superscriptsubscript𝐵11\bar{B}E^{-1}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}*&B_{2}\\ &B_{1}\end{array}\right),\quad\text{and}\quad E\bar{A}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}A_{1}&A_{2}\\ 0&B_{1}^{-1}\end{array}\right).

Since |E​A¯|=1𝐸¯𝐴1|E\bar{A}|=1 we conclude that |A1|=|B1|subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1|A_{1}|=|B_{1}|.

Let σ𝜎\sigma be some other choice of indices. If |Aσ|=|Bσ|=0subscript𝐴𝜎subscript𝐵𝜎0|A_{\sigma}|=|B_{\sigma}|=0 then there is nothing to prove. Also, since ATsuperscript𝐴𝑇A^{T} is a Gale dual of BTsuperscript𝐵𝑇B^{T}, it suffices to consider the case |Aσ|≠0subscript𝐴𝜎0|A_{\sigma}|\neq 0.

Let Pσsubscript𝑃𝜎P_{\sigma} be a permutation matrix such that A​Pσ=(Aσ,Aκ)𝐴subscript𝑃𝜎subscript𝐴𝜎subscript𝐴𝜅AP_{\sigma}=(A_{\sigma},A_{\kappa}), where the indices of σ𝜎\sigma and κ=[N]∖σ𝜅delimited-[]𝑁𝜎\kappa=[N]\setminus\sigma are ordered increasing. As above, we find an elementary matrix E𝐸E of the form (3) such that

E​A¯​P=(AσAκ0Bσ−1).𝐸¯𝐴𝑃subscript𝐴𝜎subscript𝐴𝜅0superscriptsubscript𝐵𝜎1E\bar{A}P=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}A_{\sigma}&A_{\kappa}\\ 0&B_{\sigma}^{-1}\end{array}\right).

It follows that |Aσ|=|Pσ|​|Bσ|subscript𝐴𝜎subscript𝑃𝜎subscript𝐵𝜎|A_{\sigma}|=|P_{\sigma}|\,|B_{\sigma}|, which concludes the proof. ∎

Remark 2.8.

In the algebraic case, it is natural to assume that ℤ​𝕚​𝕖​𝟡𝟝​A=ℤ​𝕚​𝕖​𝟡𝟝1+nℤ𝕚𝕖95𝐴ℤ𝕚𝕖superscript951𝑛\mathbb{Zie95}A=\mathbb{Zie95}^{1+n}, in which case A¯¯𝐴\bar{A} can be chosen as an integer unimodular matrix. That is, also B¯¯𝐵\bar{B} is integer unimodular, and hence B𝐵B is a Gale dual in the combinatorial sense. In this case we have that C​(B)=±1𝐶𝐵plus-or-minus1C(B)=\pm 1, depending on B𝐵B.

3. The Cuspidal Form

In this section we define the cuspidal form PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). To simplify notation, we impose the assumption that the top row of A𝐴A is equal to the all ones vector, and we let A^^𝐴\hat{A} denote the n×N𝑛𝑁n\times N matrix obtained from A𝐴A by deleting the top row.

Let B𝐵B denote a Gale dual of A𝐴A. The polynomial PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) depends on B𝐵B only up to an affine change of coordinates in ℂmsuperscriptℂ𝑚\mathbb{C}^{m}; we consider this dependence to be implicitly understood from the fact that PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is written as a polynomial in the variables t𝑡t.

In slight deviation from the notation in Lemma 2.7, we let ΣΣ\Sigma denote the set of all subsets σ⊂[N]𝜎delimited-[]𝑁\sigma\subset[N] of cardinality n𝑛n. For each σ∈Σ𝜎Σ\sigma\in\Sigma, let A^σsubscript^𝐴𝜎\hat{A}_{\sigma} denote the maximal cofactor of A^^𝐴\hat{A} obtained by deleting all columns corresponding to indices k∉σ𝑘𝜎k\notin\sigma.

Definition 3.1.

We define the cuspidal form PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) to be

(4) PA​(t)=∑σ∈Σ|A^σ|2​∏k∈σ⟨βk,t⟩.subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡subscript𝜎Σsuperscriptsubscript^𝐴𝜎2subscriptproduct𝑘𝜎subscript𝛽𝑘𝑡P_{A}(t)=\sum_{\sigma\in\Sigma}\left|\hat{A}_{\sigma}\right|^{2}\,\prod_{k\in\sigma}\langle\beta_{k},t\rangle.

The cuspidal form PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is a homogeneous form of degree n𝑛n in the coordinates t𝑡t. Hence it defines, in the case that it is nontrivial, a hypersurface in ℙm−1superscriptℙ𝑚1\mathbb{P}^{m-1}. (Except, of course, for the case m=1𝑚1m=1.) As PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is defined only up to choice of coordinates one can not, in general, ask for a combinatorial interpretation of its coefficients. When there is a canonical choice of coordinates there is, however, reasonable interpretation.

Example 3.2.

Let A𝐴A be a pyramid. That is, there is a point α∈A𝛼𝐴\alpha\in A such that A∖{α}𝐴𝛼A\setminus\{\alpha\} is contained in an affine space of dimension n−1𝑛1n-1. This is equivalent to that βα=0subscript𝛽𝛼0\beta_{\alpha}=0. Thus, if α∈σ𝛼𝜎\alpha\in\sigma then ⟨βα,t⟩=0subscript𝛽𝛼𝑡0\langle\beta_{\alpha},t\rangle=0, and if α≠σ𝛼𝜎\alpha\neq\sigma then |A^σ|=0subscript^𝐴𝜎0|\hat{A}_{\sigma}|=0. Hence, each term of (4) vanishes, implying that PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is trivial.

Example 3.3.

Let m=1𝑚1m=1, and let Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k} denote the (n+1)×(n+1)𝑛1𝑛1(n+1)\times(n+1) submatrix of A𝐴A obtained by deleting the k𝑘kth entry and assume, without loss of generality, that α1=(1,0,…,0)Tsubscript𝛼1superscript10…0𝑇\alpha_{1}=(1,0,\dots,0)^{T}. Then, each σ∈Σ𝜎Σ\sigma\in\Sigma containing 111 has |A^σ|=0subscript^𝐴𝜎0|\hat{A}_{\sigma}|=0, and each σ𝜎\sigma not containing 111 has |A^σ|=|Ak|subscript^𝐴𝜎subscript𝐴𝑘|\hat{A}_{\sigma}|=|A_{k}| where k=k​(σ)𝑘𝑘𝜎k=k(\sigma) is the unique index greater than 111 not contained in σ𝜎\sigma. By Lemma 2.7 we can choose a Gale dual B𝐵B according to the rule that βk=(−1)k​|Ak|subscript𝛽𝑘superscript1𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘\beta_{k}=(-1)^{k}|A_{k}|. Hence,

PA​(t)=tn​(∏k>1(−1)k​|Ak|)​∑k>1(−1)k​|Ak|=sgn⁡(n)​tn​∏k=0n+2|Ak|subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡superscript𝑡𝑛subscriptproduct𝑘1superscript1𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘subscript𝑘1superscript1𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘sgn𝑛superscript𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘0𝑛2subscript𝐴𝑘P_{A}(t)=t^{n}\,\Big{(}\prod_{k>1}(-1)^{k}|A_{k}|\Big{)}\sum_{k>1}(-1)^{k}|A_{k}|=\operatorname{sgn}(n)\,t^{n}\,\prod_{k=0}^{n+2}|A_{k}|

where sgn⁡(n)=(−1)(n2)sgn𝑛superscript1binomial𝑛2\operatorname{sgn}(n)=(-1)^{{n\choose 2}}. Notice, in particular, that PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is trivial if and only if |Ak|=0subscript𝐴𝑘0|A_{k}|=0 for some k𝑘k, which is equivalent to that A𝐴A is a pyramid.

Theorem 3.4.

We have that f=Φ​(ω;t)𝑓Φ𝜔𝑡f=\Phi(\omega;t) is a cusp of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} if and only if PA​(t)=0subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡0P_{A}(t)=0.

Proof.

3.2. Katz’ Theorem

In the algebraic case, it follows from Katz’ dimension formula [9], see also [7, §1.5], that the Jacobian J​(ω;t)𝐽𝜔𝑡J(\omega;t) has full rank at (ω;t)𝜔𝑡(\omega;t) if and only if the Hessian matrix Hf​(w)subscript𝐻𝑓𝑤H_{f}(w) of f=Φ​(ω;t)𝑓Φ𝜔𝑡f=\Phi(\omega;t) at the point w=−ω𝑤𝜔w=-\omega is singular. This statement remains true if one generalizes to exponential sums. It is possible to obtain a proof if this fact by making the appropriate modifications to the exposition in [7, §1.5]; since we have introduced the cuspidal form (4) we prefer the following more direct approach.

Theorem 3.5.

Let f=Φ​(ω;t)∈XˇA𝑓Φ𝜔𝑡subscriptˇ𝑋𝐴f=\Phi(\omega;t)\in\check{X}_{A}. Then, the Hessian matrix Hf​(w)subscript𝐻𝑓𝑤H_{f}(w) is singular at w=−ω𝑤𝜔w=-\omega if and only if PA​(t)=0subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡0P_{A}(t)=0. In particular, if XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is a hypersurface and f𝑓f is a smooth point on XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A}, then the Hessian matrix Hf​(−ω)subscript𝐻𝑓𝜔H_{f}(-\omega) is nonsingular.

Proof.

We only need to prove the first part. As in the proof of Theorem 3.4 the torus action can be quoted out. Hence, it suffices to consider the case ω=0𝜔0\omega=0, where the singular point is located at w=0𝑤0w=0. We have that

fk​l′′​(0)=∑j=1Nαj​k​αj​l​⟨βj,t⟩,1≤k,l≤n.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑓′′𝑘𝑙0superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑗𝑘subscript𝛼𝑗𝑙subscript𝛽𝑗𝑡formulae-sequence1𝑘𝑙𝑛f^{\prime\prime}_{kl}(0)=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\alpha_{jk}\alpha_{jl}\langle\beta_{j},t\rangle,\quad 1\leq k,l\leq n.

In particular, the p𝑝pth column Hpsubscript𝐻𝑝H_{p} of Hf​(1)subscript𝐻𝑓1H_{f}(1), for p=1,…,n𝑝1…𝑛p=1,\dots,n is a sum of N𝑁N vectors

Hp=∑j=1Nαj​p​⟨βj,t⟩​α^j.subscript𝐻𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑗𝑝subscript𝛽𝑗𝑡subscript^𝛼𝑗H_{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\alpha_{jp}\langle\beta_{j},t\rangle\,\hat{\alpha}_{j}.

For any two such columns, the j𝑗jth summands are both multiples of α^jsubscript^𝛼𝑗\hat{\alpha}_{j}. In particular, we can expand the determinant

|Hf​(0)|=∑σ∈Σ∑π|αk​π​(k)​⟨βk,t⟩​α^k|k∈σsubscript𝐻𝑓0subscript𝜎Σsubscript𝜋subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝜋𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘𝑡subscript^𝛼𝑘𝑘𝜎\left|H_{f}(0)\right|=\sum_{\sigma\in\Sigma}\,\sum_{\pi}\,\left|\alpha_{k\pi(k)}\langle\beta_{k},t\rangle\,\hat{\alpha}_{k}\right|_{k\in\sigma}

which completes the proof. ∎

4. Properties of the Cuspidal Form

In this section we investigate the cuspidal form PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) as a function of the spectrum A𝐴A.

4.1. Sub-configurations of A𝐴A

Theorem 4.1.

Let α∈A𝛼𝐴\alpha\in A be such that A∖{α}𝐴𝛼A\setminus\{\alpha\} has rank 1+n1𝑛1+n, let t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime} be coordinates in βα∗superscriptsubscript𝛽𝛼\beta_{\alpha}^{*} and t=(t′,tm)𝑡superscript𝑡′subscript𝑡𝑚t=(t^{\prime},t_{m}) coordinates in ℂmsuperscriptℂ𝑚\mathbb{C}^{m}. Then,

PA∖{α}​(t′)=PA​(t)|βα∗.subscript𝑃𝐴𝛼superscript𝑡′evaluated-atsubscript𝑃𝐴𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛽𝛼P_{A\setminus\{\alpha\}}(t^{\prime})=P_{A}(t)\big{|}_{\beta_{\alpha}^{*}}.
Proof.

By assumption, if we write A=(A′,α)𝐴superscript𝐴′𝛼A=(A^{\prime},\alpha), then A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime} is of rank 1+n1𝑛1+n and codimension m−1𝑚1m-1. We can chose a Gale dual B𝐵B of A𝐴A of the form

B=(B′∗01),𝐵superscript𝐵′01B=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}B^{\prime}&*\\ 0&1\end{array}\right),

where B′superscript𝐵′B^{\prime} is a Gale dual of A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}. The theorem follows from that the restriction of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) to βα∗superscriptsubscript𝛽𝛼\beta_{\alpha}^{*} is given by tm=0subscript𝑡𝑚0t_{m}=0. First, for any σ∈Σ𝜎Σ\sigma\in\Sigma with N∈σ𝑁𝜎N\in\sigma, we have that the term of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) corresponding to σ𝜎\sigma has the monomial tmsubscript𝑡𝑚t_{m} as a factor. Second, we have that ⟨βk,t⟩subscript𝛽𝑘𝑡\langle\beta_{k},t\rangle restricted to tm=0subscript𝑡𝑚0t_{m}=0 equals ⟨βk′,t′⟩superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘′superscript𝑡′\langle\beta_{k}^{\prime},t^{\prime}\rangle for any k=1,…,N−1𝑘1…𝑁1k=1,\dots,N-1. ∎

Corollary 4.2.

If A′⊂Asuperscript𝐴′𝐴A^{\prime}\subset A is such that PA′subscript𝑃superscript𝐴′P_{A^{\prime}} is nontrivial, then PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} is nontrivial. ∎

4.2. Diagonal and upper diagonal configurations

Definition 4.3.

We say that a point configuration A𝐴A is upper diagonal if it can, after acting by GL1+n⁡(ℝ)subscriptGL1𝑛ℝ\operatorname{GL}_{1+n}(\mathbb{R}), be written in the form

(5) A=(111⋯10A~1∗⋯∗00A~2⋯∗⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮000⋯A~j),𝐴111⋯10subscript~𝐴1⋯00subscript~𝐴2⋯⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮000⋯subscript~𝐴𝑗A=\left(\begin{array}[]{ccccc}1&1&1&\cdots&1\\ 0&\tilde{A}_{1}&*&\cdots&*\\ 0&0&\tilde{A}_{2}&\cdots&*\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ 0&0&0&\cdots&\tilde{A}_{j}\end{array}\right),

where we associate to each A~jsubscript~𝐴𝑗\tilde{A}_{j} the point configuration Ajsubscript𝐴𝑗A_{j} defined by A^j=(0,A~j)subscript^𝐴𝑗0subscript~𝐴𝑗\hat{A}_{j}=(0,\tilde{A}_{j}). The configurations Ajsubscript𝐴𝑗A_{j} for j=1,…​m𝑗1…𝑚j=1,\dots m are called the diagonal configurations of A𝐴A. If all elements marked by ∗* vanishes, then the point configuration is said to be diagonal.

Remark 4.4.

A configuration A𝐴A is an iterated circuit in the sense of Esterov [4, Def. 3.15] if and only if after applying an integer affine transformation it is an upper diagonal configuration all of whose diagonal configurations are circuits.

Theorem 4.5.

Let A𝐴A be a diagonal point configuration with diagonal configurations A1subscript𝐴1A_{1}, …, Amsubscript𝐴𝑚A_{m}. Then, PA​(t)=PA1​(t1)​⋯​PAm​(tm)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡subscript𝑃subscript𝐴1subscript𝑡1⋯subscript𝑃subscript𝐴𝑚subscript𝑡𝑚P_{A}(t)=P_{A_{1}}(t_{1})\cdots P_{A_{m}}(t_{m}).

Proof.

By induction, it suffices to consider the case m=2𝑚2m=2. For a minor |A^σ|subscript^𝐴𝜎|\hat{A}_{\sigma}| of A^^𝐴\hat{A} to be nonvanishing, it must hold that the set σ∈Σ𝜎Σ\sigma\in\Sigma consists of njsubscript𝑛𝑗n_{j} columns corresponding to points in A~jsubscript~𝐴𝑗\tilde{A}_{j} for j=1,2𝑗12j=1,2. Therefor, for each non-vanishing term of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) we have the factorization

|Aσ|=|Aσ1|​|Aσ2|subscript𝐴𝜎subscript𝐴subscript𝜎1subscript𝐴subscript𝜎2|A_{\sigma}|=|A_{\sigma_{1}}|\,|A_{\sigma_{2}}|

where σj∈Σjsubscript𝜎𝑗subscriptΣ𝑗\sigma_{j}\in\Sigma_{j} for j=1,2𝑗12j=1,2 and σ=σ1∪σ2𝜎subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2\sigma=\sigma_{1}\cup\sigma_{2}. We can write Ajsubscript𝐴𝑗A_{j} and its Gale dual in the block forms

Aj=(110A~j) and Bj=(∗B~j).formulae-sequencesubscript𝐴𝑗110subscript~𝐴𝑗 and subscript𝐵𝑗subscript~𝐵𝑗A_{j}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}1&1\\ 0&\tilde{A}_{j}\end{array}\right)\quad\text{ and }\quad B_{j}=\left(\begin{array}[]{c}*\\ \tilde{B}_{j}\end{array}\right).

Then, a Gale dual of A𝐴A can be written as

B=(∗∗B~100B~2).𝐵subscript~𝐵100subscript~𝐵2B=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}*&*\\ \tilde{B}_{1}&0\\ 0&\tilde{B}_{2}\end{array}\right).

Hence, for each σ=σ1∪σ2𝜎subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2\sigma=\sigma_{1}\cup\sigma_{2} it holds that

∏k∈σ⟨βk,t⟩=(∏k∈σ1⟨βk,t1⟩)​(∏k∈σ2⟨βk,t2⟩),subscriptproduct𝑘𝜎subscript𝛽𝑘𝑡subscriptproduct𝑘subscript𝜎1subscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝑡1subscriptproduct𝑘subscript𝜎2subscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝑡2\prod_{k\in\sigma}\langle\beta_{k},t\rangle=\left(\prod_{k\in\sigma_{1}}\langle\beta_{k},t_{1}\rangle\right)\left(\prod_{k\in\sigma_{2}}\langle\beta_{k},t_{2}\rangle\right),

where we, by abuse of notation, interpret βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} as a row both of B𝐵B and of B~jsubscript~𝐵𝑗\tilde{B}_{j} when k∈σj𝑘subscript𝜎𝑗k\in\sigma_{j}. ∎

Remark 4.6.

Let A𝐴A be an iterated circuit. By Example 3.3, we have that PAj​(tj)subscript𝑃subscript𝐴𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗P_{A_{j}}(t_{j}) is a non-trivial monomial in the single variable tjsubscript𝑡𝑗t_{j} of degree njsubscript𝑛𝑗n_{j} for each j=1,…,m𝑗1…𝑚j=1,\dots,m. It is straightforward to check that the coefficient of the monomial t1n1​t2n2​⋯​tmnmsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1subscript𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑡2subscript𝑛2⋯superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚t_{1}^{n_{1}}t_{2}^{n_{2}}\cdots t_{m}^{n_{m}} is unchanged if one deletes all the elements of A𝐴A marked by a star in (5). In particular, it follows from Theorem 4.5 that the monomial of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) with exponent vector (n1,n2,…,nm)subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2…subscript𝑛𝑚(n_{1},n_{2},\dots,n_{m}) is given by PA1​(t1)⋅PA2​(t2)​⋯​PAm​(tm)⋅subscript𝑃subscript𝐴1subscript𝑡1subscript𝑃subscript𝐴2subscript𝑡2⋯subscript𝑃subscript𝐴𝑚subscript𝑡𝑚P_{A_{1}}(t_{1})\cdot P_{A_{2}}(t_{2})\cdots P_{A_{m}}(t_{m}). In particular, PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is nontrivial in this case.

5. Linear Factors

Corollary 5.1.

Let α∈A𝛼𝐴\alpha\in A. If the cuspidal form PA∖{α}subscript𝑃𝐴𝛼P_{A\setminus\{\alpha\}} is trivial, then ⟨βα,t⟩subscript𝛽𝛼𝑡\langle\beta_{\alpha},t\rangle divides PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t).

Proof.

This follows from Theorem 4.1 and Hilbert’s Nullstellensatz. ∎

Example 5.2.

Consider the point configuration and Gale dual

A=(111110120100012)andBT=(2−10−211−2100).formulae-sequence𝐴111110120100012andsuperscript𝐵𝑇2102112100A=\left(\begin{array}[]{ccccc}1&1&1&1&1\\ 0&1&2&0&1\\ 0&0&0&1&2\end{array}\right)\quad\text{and}\quad B^{T}=\left(\begin{array}[]{rrrrr}2&-1&0&-2&1\\ 1&-2&1&0&0\end{array}\right).

Deleting any of the two last columns of A𝐴A we obtain a pyramid, which has trivial cuspidal form by Example 3.2. Notice that the corresponding rows of the Gale dual B𝐵B are parallel. The cuspidal form in this case is PA​(t)=4​t1​(t2−t1)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡4subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2subscript𝑡1P_{A}(t)=4t_{1}(t_{2}-t_{1}). In particular, Corollary 5.1 can not be extended to a bijective correspondence between α∈A𝛼𝐴\alpha\in A with PA∖{α}subscript𝑃𝐴𝛼P_{A\setminus\{\alpha\}} trivial and linear factors of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t).

Proposition 5.3.

Let A𝐴A be a point configuration such that PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is non-trivial. Assume that one (and therefor every) Gale dual B𝐵B has a set of k𝑘k parallel rows β1,…,βksubscript𝛽1…subscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{1},\dots,\beta_{k}. Then, ⟨β,t⟩k−1superscript𝛽𝑡𝑘1\langle\beta,t\rangle^{k-1} divides PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). If, in addition, β1+⋯+βk=0subscript𝛽1⋯subscript𝛽𝑘0\beta_{1}+\dots+\beta_{k}=0, then ⟨β,t⟩ksuperscript𝛽𝑡𝑘\langle\beta,t\rangle^{k} divides PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t).

Let βj=γj​βsubscript𝛽𝑗subscript𝛾𝑗𝛽\beta_{j}=\gamma_{j}\beta for some β≠0𝛽0\beta\neq 0 and scalars γjsubscript𝛾𝑗\gamma_{j} for j=1,…,k𝑗1…𝑘j=1,\dots,k. By Lemma 2.7, any maximal minor of A𝐴A not containing all but at most one of the columns α1,…,αksubscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{1},\dots,\alpha_{k} vanishes. In particular, the remaining points α^k+1,…,α^Nsubscript^𝛼𝑘1…subscript^𝛼𝑁\hat{\alpha}_{k+1},\dots,\hat{\alpha}_{N} are contained in some n−k+1𝑛𝑘1n-k+1-dimensional affine subspace. Since A𝐴A has full rank we can write A𝐴A in the form (where we have reordered so that α1,…,αksubscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{1},\dots,\alpha_{k} are the k𝑘k last columns)

(6) A=(111A^′∗∗0Ik−1γ)andB=(B′∗0−γ01).formulae-sequence𝐴111superscript^𝐴′0subscript𝐼𝑘1𝛾and𝐵superscript𝐵′0𝛾01A=\left(\begin{array}[]{ccc}1&1&1\\ \hat{A}^{\prime}&*&*\\ 0&I_{k-1}&\gamma\end{array}\right)\quad\text{and}\quad B=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}B^{\prime}&*\\ 0&-\gamma\\ 0&1\end{array}\right).

Here, A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime} is an (n−k+2)×(N−k)𝑛𝑘2𝑁𝑘(n-k+2)\times(N-k)-matrix with Gale dual B′superscript𝐵′B^{\prime}, and γ∈ℝk−1𝛾superscriptℝ𝑘1\gamma\in\mathbb{R}^{k-1}. ∑σ∈Σ′|A^σ′|2​(∏j∈σ⟨βj′,t′⟩)​((∏j=1k−1(−γj))+∑i=1k−1γi2​∏j≠i(−γj))=(−1)k−1​γ1​⋯​γk−1​(1−|γ|)​PA^​(t′).subscript𝜎superscriptΣ′superscriptsubscriptsuperscript^𝐴′𝜎2subscriptproduct𝑗𝜎subscriptsuperscript𝛽′𝑗superscript𝑡′superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝑘1subscript𝛾𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑖2subscriptproduct𝑗𝑖subscript𝛾𝑗superscript1𝑘1subscript𝛾1⋯subscript𝛾𝑘11𝛾subscript𝑃^𝐴superscript𝑡′\sum_{\sigma\in\Sigma^{\prime}}\,\left|\hat{A}^{\prime}_{\sigma}\right|^{2}\,\Big{(}\prod_{j\in\sigma}\langle\beta^{\prime}_{j},t^{\prime}\rangle\Big{)}\,\left(\bigg{(}\prod_{j=1}^{k-1}(-\gamma_{j})\bigg{)}+\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\gamma_{i}^{2}\prod_{j\neq i}(-\gamma_{j})\right)=(-1)^{k-1}\,\gamma_{1}\cdots\gamma_{k-1}\,\left(1-|\gamma|\right)\,P_{\hat{A}}(t^{\prime}).

6. Defect Duals

A point configuration A𝐴A and, in the algebraic case, the toric variety XAsubscript𝑋𝐴X_{A}, is said to be dual defective if the dual variety XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} has codimension at least 222. The following theorem is an immediate consequence of the properties of the Jacobian matrix.

Theorem 6.1.

The point configuration A𝐴A is dual defective if and only if PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is trivial.

Proof.

If A𝐴A is dual defective, then the rank of the Jacobian matrix J​(w;t)𝐽𝑤𝑡J(w;t) is at most n+m−1𝑛𝑚1n+m-1 for generic (w;t)𝑤𝑡(w;t). It follows that its maximal minors, which are polynomial in (w;t)𝑤𝑡(w;t), vanishes for generic (w;t)𝑤𝑡(w;t), and hence they vanishes identically. Conversely, if XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is a hypersurface, as the smooth locus of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is nonempty, we can find a point f=Φ​(w;t)𝑓Φ𝑤𝑡f=\Phi(w;t) for which the Jacobian matrix J​(w;t)𝐽𝑤𝑡J(w;t) has rank n+m𝑛𝑚n+m. ∎

Example 6.2.

Let A𝐴A be a pyramid. We saw in Example 3.2 that the polynomial PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is trivial, implying (the well-known result) that XAsubscript𝑋𝐴X_{A} is dual defective.

Proposition 6.3.

If A𝐴A has a subset A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}, of full dimension, such that A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime} is not dual defective, then A𝐴A is not dual defective.

Proof.

This (well-known result) follows from Corollary 4.2. ∎

Let us now recover Esterov’s results on dual defective point configuration from [4, Lem. 3.17] and [5, Cor. 3.20], and extend it from the algebraic case to the case of exponential sums.

Theorem 6.4.

A specturm A⊂ℝ1+n𝐴superscriptℝ1𝑛A\subset\mathbb{R}^{1+n} is dual defective if and only if A𝐴A does not contain any iterated circuit.

Proof.

By Theorem 6.1 and Proposition 6.3 we translate to the equivalent statement that PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is trivial if and only if A𝐴A does not contain an iterated circuit. The only if-direction was proven in Remark 4.6.

Let us prove the if-direction. Assume that PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is nontrivial. We use a double induction over the codimension m𝑚m and the dimension n𝑛n, where the base cases m=1𝑚1m=1 for arbitrary dimension is covered by Example 3.3.

If PA∖{α}​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝛼𝑡P_{A\setminus\{\alpha\}}(t) is nontrivial for some α∈A𝛼𝐴\alpha\in A then, by induction on codimension, A∖{α}𝐴𝛼A\setminus\{\alpha\} contains an iterated circuit, implying that A𝐴A contains an iterated circuit as well. Hence, it suffices to consider the case when PA∖{α}subscript𝑃𝐴𝛼P_{A\setminus\{\alpha\}} is trivial for all α∈A𝛼𝐴\alpha\in A.

By Corollary 5.1, we have that ⟨β,t⟩𝛽𝑡\langle\beta,t\rangle divides PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) for all rows β𝛽\beta of B𝐵B. However, B𝐵B has N𝑁N rows, while PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is a homogeneous, nontrivial, polynomial of degree n𝑛n. By the pigeon hole principle, the Gale dual B𝐵B must have parallel rows. For a family β1,…,βksubscript𝛽1…subscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{1},\dots,\beta_{k} of parallel rows of B𝐵B, where k>1𝑘1k>1, let us borrow the notation from the proof of Proposition 5.3: that βj=γj​βsubscript𝛽𝑗subscript𝛾𝑗𝛽\beta_{j}=\gamma_{j}\beta for some scalars γj≠0subscript𝛾𝑗0\gamma_{j}\neq 0 for j=1,…,k𝑗1…𝑘j=1,\dots,k, and for some β≠0𝛽0\beta\neq 0. Then, again by a comparison of the number of rows of B𝐵B and the degree of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t), there must exist a family, β1,…,βksubscript𝛽1…subscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{1},\dots,\beta_{k} of parallel rows of B𝐵B, with k>1𝑘1k>1, such that ⟨β,t⟩ksuperscript𝛽𝑡𝑘\langle\beta,t\rangle^{k} does not divide PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). Let us fix such a family.

Let us write A𝐴A and B𝐵B as in (6), and let γ=(γ1,…,γk)T𝛾superscriptsubscript𝛾1…subscript𝛾𝑘𝑇\gamma=(\gamma_{1},\dots,\gamma_{k})^{T} be as in that proof. Since ⟨β,t⟩ksuperscript𝛽𝑡𝑘\langle\beta,t\rangle^{k} does not divide PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t), we have that |γk|≠1subscript𝛾𝑘1|\gamma_{k}|\neq 1. Therefor, the k×k𝑘𝑘k\times k-submatrix of A𝐴A

(11Ik−1γ)11subscript𝐼𝑘1𝛾\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}1&1\\ I_{k-1}&\gamma\end{array}\right)

has rank k𝑘k. (Recall that each γk≠0subscript𝛾𝑘0\gamma_{k}\neq 0, for otherwise A𝐴A is a pyramid.) This has two consequences. First, we have that (0,Ik−1,γ)0subscript𝐼𝑘1𝛾(0,I_{k-1},\gamma) is a k𝑘k-dimensional circuit. Second, by applying an integer affine transformation, we can eliminate all entries marked by ∗* in (6). Thus, by Theorem 4.5, and with the notation of (6), it holds that PA′​(t)subscript𝑃superscript𝐴′𝑡P_{A^{\prime}}(t) is a factor of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). In particular, PA′​(t)subscript𝑃superscript𝐴′𝑡P_{A^{\prime}}(t) is nontrivial, and hence A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime} contains an iterated circuit of dimension k−1𝑘1k-1, by induction on codimension and dimension. It follows that A𝐴A contains an iterated circuit. ∎

7. Rationality of the Cuspidal Locus

Let A𝐴A be algebraic. Consider the case n=1𝑛1n=1, which was studied in detail in [11], and where the cuspidal form PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) appeared in this special case. As n=1𝑛1n=1 the cuspidal form is, for every m𝑚m, a non-trivial linear form in t𝑡t vanishing along some hyperplane in ℙm−1superscriptℙ𝑚1\mathbb{P}^{m-1}. In particular, the cuspidal locus of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is always unirational, and if it is a subvariety of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} of codimension one, then it is rational. Actually, a stronger statement holds: there is a point configuration E𝐸E such that the cuspidal locus of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is isomorphic to the discriminantal variety XˇEsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐸\check{X}_{E}. Let us here explain the corresponding result for general n𝑛n.

Theorem 7.1.

Let A𝐴A be algebraic. For each linear factor ⟨ℓ,t⟩ℓ𝑡\langle\ell,t\rangle of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t), such that ℓℓ\ell is not proportional to any row of the Gale dual B𝐵B, there is an algebraic point configuration E𝐸E whose discriminant XˇEsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐸\check{X}_{E} is birational to a subvariety of the cuspidal locus of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A}.

Proof.

In the algebraic case it suffices to consider the reduced discriminant of Kapranov [8] mentioned in Remark 2.5. Its Horn–Kapranov uniformazation ΨA​(t)subscriptΨ𝐴𝑡\Psi_{A}(t) is given by t↦Φ​(1;t)B=(B​t)Bmaps-to𝑡Φsuperscript1𝑡𝐵superscript𝐵𝑡𝐵t\mapsto\Phi(1;t)^{B}=(Bt)^{B}.

Let s𝑠s denote coordinates in ℓ∗superscriptℓ\ell^{*}. Let ⟨ℓ,t⟩ℓ𝑡\langle\ell,t\rangle be a linear factor of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t), where ℓℓ\ell is not proportional to any row of the Gale dual B𝐵B. The hyperplane ℓ∗superscriptℓ\ell^{*} can be written in implicit form, as the image a linear transformation L:ℙm−2→ℙm−1:𝐿→superscriptℙ𝑚2superscriptℙ𝑚1L\colon\mathbb{P}^{m-2}\rightarrow\mathbb{P}^{m-1}. Notice that L𝐿L can be chosen as an integer matrix. Since A​B​L=0𝐴𝐵𝐿0ABL=0, we can extend A𝐴A (by adding one extra row) to an integer matrix E𝐸E such that we have an exact sequence

It follows that (ΨA∘L)L=ΨEsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝐴𝐿𝐿subscriptΨ𝐸\left(\Psi_{A}\circ L\right)^{L}=\Psi_{E}, and hence (ΨA∘L)LsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝐴𝐿𝐿\left(\Psi_{A}\circ L\right)^{L} is a birational morphism from ℓ∗superscriptℓ\ell^{*} to XˇEsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐸\check{X}_{E}. ∎

The singular locus of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is in general not birational to a discriminant variety. That is, it is in general not rational. Let us give a simple example.

Example 7.2.

Let n=3𝑛3n=3 and N=7𝑁7N=7, so that PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is a cubic form in three variables. In particular, if PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is non-singular then the cuspidal locus of XˇAsubscriptˇ𝑋𝐴\check{X}_{A} is birational to a smooth cubic curve. Such a curve is unirational but not rational. For an explicit example then PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is non-singular we present the point configuration

A=(1111111011233330221230322230).𝐴1111111011233330221230322230A=\left(\begin{array}[]{ccccccc}1&1&1&1&1&1&1\\ 0&1&1&2&3&3&3\\ 3&0&2&2&1&2&3\\ 0&3&2&2&2&3&0\end{array}\right).

8. The Bivariate Case: The Signature of the Quadratic Form

In the case that n=2𝑛2n=2 the polynomial PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t) is a quadratic form. Being defined only up to choice of coordinates, let us in this section consider the (real) invariants given by the rank and the signature of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t).

Theorem 8.1.

Let n=2𝑛2n=2 and let sAsubscript𝑠𝐴s_{A} denote the signature of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). Then,

  1. i)

    sA=(0,0;m)subscript𝑠𝐴00𝑚s_{A}=(0,0;m) if and only if A𝐴A is a pyramid.

  2. ii)

    sA=(1,0;0)subscript𝑠𝐴100s_{A}=(1,0;0) if and only if A𝐴A is contained in a non-real parabola.

  3. iii)

    sA=(0,1;m−1)subscript𝑠𝐴01𝑚1s_{A}=(0,1;m-1) if and only if A𝐴A is contained in a real parabola.

  4. iv)

    sA=(1,1;m−2)subscript𝑠𝐴11𝑚2s_{A}=(1,1;m-2) if and only if A𝐴A is contained in a hyperbola.

  5. v)

    sA=(0,2;m−2)subscript𝑠𝐴02𝑚2s_{A}=(0,2;m-2) if and only if A𝐴A is contained in an ellipse.

  6. vi)

    sA=(1,2;m−3)subscript𝑠𝐴12𝑚3s_{A}=(1,2;m-3) in all other cases.

Remark 8.2.

In the case of codimension m=1𝑚1m=1 it follows from Theorem 8.1 (and also from Example 3.3) that the combinatorial type of A𝐴A is determined by the signature of PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). Indeed, A𝐴A is a simplex circuit if and only if sA=(1,0;0)subscript𝑠𝐴100s_{A}=(1,0;0), it is a vertex circuit if and only if sA=(0,1;0)subscript𝑠𝐴010s_{A}=(0,1;0), and it is a pyramid if and only if sA=(0,0;1)subscript𝑠𝐴001s_{A}=(0,0;1).

Lemma 8.7.

Proof.

The general equation of a conic passing through the points 0,e10subscript𝑒10,e_{1}, and e2subscript𝑒2e_{2} is P​(x)=0𝑃𝑥0P(x)=0 where

(12) P​(x)=a​x12+b​x1​x2+c​x22−a​x1−c​x2𝑃𝑥𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑥12𝑏subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑥22𝑎subscript𝑥1𝑐subscript𝑥2P(x)=ax_{1}^{2}+bx_{1}x_{2}+cx_{2}^{2}-ax_{1}-cx_{2}

Requiring in addition that the conic passes through α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1} and α2subscript𝛼2\alpha_{2} gives the coefficients, up to multiplication by a constant,

{a=−α12​α22​(α11−α21+α12​α21−α11​α22)b=α12​α21​(1−α12)​(1−α21)−α11​α22​(1−α11)​(1−α22)c=α11​α21​(α12−α12​α21−α22+α11​α22)cases𝑎subscript𝛼12subscript𝛼22subscript𝛼11subscript𝛼21subscript𝛼12subscript𝛼21subscript𝛼11subscript𝛼22𝑏subscript𝛼12subscript𝛼211subscript𝛼121subscript𝛼21subscript𝛼11subscript𝛼221subscript𝛼111subscript𝛼22𝑐subscript𝛼11subscript𝛼21subscript𝛼12subscript𝛼12subscript𝛼21subscript𝛼22subscript𝛼11subscript𝛼22\left\{\begin{array}[]{lll}a&=&-\alpha_{12}\alpha_{22}(\alpha_{11}-\alpha_{21}+\alpha_{12}\alpha_{21}-\alpha_{11}\alpha_{22})\\ b&=&\alpha_{12}\alpha_{21}(1-\alpha_{12})(1-\alpha_{21})-\alpha_{11}\alpha_{22}(1-\alpha_{11})(1-\alpha_{22})\\ c&=&\alpha_{11}\alpha_{21}(\alpha_{12}-\alpha_{12}\alpha_{21}-\alpha_{22}+\alpha_{11}\alpha_{22})\end{array}\right.

We leave it for the reader to verify that, with these coefficients, the polynomia P​(x)𝑃𝑥P(x) evaluated at x=α3𝑥subscript𝛼3x=\alpha_{3} is equal to H​(α1,α2,α3)𝐻subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2subscript𝛼3H(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\alpha_{3}). ∎

Proof of Theorem 8.1.

It is well known that for n=2𝑛2n=2 the point configuration A𝐴A is dual defective if and only A𝐴A is a pyramid. This proves part (i) of the theorem.

If the codimension m=1𝑚1m=1, then A𝐴A consists of four points in the plane, through which two parabolas pass. It can be seen from (11) that the limiting case between real and non-real parabolas is the case of a pyramid. Thus, this case follows from Example 3.3.

We now assume that m>1𝑚1m>1. Classical geometry says that there is a unique conic passing through five points in generic position (i.e., no four are colinear) in the plane. We allow the conic to be degenerate. Assuming that A𝐴A is not a pyramid, it has a subconfiguration A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} of five points in generic position. Let A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} constitute the first five columns of (7).

Let us first prove the relaxed statement, where we only consider the rank of the cuspidal form PA​(t)subscript𝑃𝐴𝑡P_{A}(t). It follows from Lemma 8.4 that the rank is at most three.

If the rank is at most two, then by Lemma 8.7 any choice of six points of A𝐴A is contained in a conic. However, the five points of A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} determine a unique conic C𝐶C. By adjoining the remaining points one-by-one, we conclude that A𝐴A is contained in the conic C𝐶C. Conversely, if A𝐴A is contained in a conic, then G3subscript𝐺3G_{3} vanishes for all α𝛼\alpha and δ𝛿\delta by (9).

If the rank is at most one, then by Lemma 8.5 any choice of five points is contained in a parabola. In particular, the five points of A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} are contained in a parabola C𝐶C. Let α𝛼\alpha be an additional point. Then, by Lemma 8.7, A1∪{α}subscript𝐴1𝛼A_{1}\cup\{\alpha\} is contained in a conic. But C𝐶C is the unique conic containing A1subscript𝐴1A_{1}, so α∈C𝛼𝐶\alpha\in C. It follows that A𝐴A is contained in C𝐶C. Conversely, if A𝐴A is contained in a parabola, then G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} vanishes for all α𝛼\alpha and δ𝛿\delta by Lemma 8.5 and Remark 8.6.

Let us now turn to the refined statement of Theorem 8.1 regarding signatures. For each class in the above list, it suffices to consider the minimal m𝑚m such that there is a point configuration in this class. Indeed, there is a “minimal” subconfiguration witnessing the class containing A𝐴A, and by Theorem 4.1 we can delete the remaining points without altering the rank. In particular, parts (ii) and (iii) follows from the above discussion on codimension m=1𝑚1m=1.

Any two minimal configurations of one class can be continuously deformed to each other without leaving the class in question. Therefor, it suffices to consider one representative of each class. Since a generic configuration can be continuously deformed to a configuration contained either in an ellipse or in a parabola, part (vi) follows from parts (iv) and (v) and the fact that the rank is 333 in the generic case. Hence, we finish the proof with Examples 8.8 and 8.9. ∎
